awd_titl_txt: Theory and implementation of exceptional points of degeneracy for oscillators and array radiators based on spatial combiners
awd_abstract_narration:
High performance electronics is important in a variety of societal applications. Improvements based on the proposed research effort are expected to be significant in terms of energy-efficient electronics and of the quality of the generated oscillating frequency, which are both key features in modern electronic systems. The proposed work explores a new method to generate electromagnetic waves with stable frequencies with low noise and without wasting power. It is expected that the power necessary to provide oscillations is between one-half and one-tenth of that used by conventional oscillators design techniques. The other major outcome of the proposed research is an improved way to generate radiated high power in an efficient fashion, while being technologically simpler than other current solutions. It is known that high power generation at millimeter waves is notoriously challenging because single sources realized using semiconductors cannot provide high power levels. The solution adopted in this work is based on combining the power radiated by many individual radiating oscillators; thanks to a self-locking effect due to the degeneracy condition the oscillation frequency is expected to be pure, i.e., have low noise, and to produce high power radiation levels at a specific direction. Although the research is focused on exploring how to use for the first time the degeneracy condition in radio frequency systems, the acquired theoretical knowledge will also be useful for solving a variety of other problems, such as making highly sensitive sensors. The investigators will provide interdisciplinary training to participating graduate students through research; they will mentor undergraduate students in research fostering diversity in science and technology; and they will disseminate research to both scientific and layman audiences for the broad population to foster interest in electromagnetics and electronics. 

The proposed research activity aims at providing first a theoretical foundation of microwave and millimeter wave (mm-wave) circuits that are based on the exceptional point of degeneracy (EPD) in coupled-mode circuits and transmission lines. Second, this research will explore and implement various novel applications such as robust conditions of oscillation in distributed oscillators and spatial power combiners made of array grid oscillators. The novelty is based on the recently discovered physical phenomenon of giant resonance in coupled waveguides that support a degenerate band edge (DBE).  A DBE is a very special degeneracy condition occurring when critical coupling is established between two or more guided modes. This proposal targets two related outcomes: (1) Theory and demonstration of a novel principle of operation for oscillators in silicon-based technology, including CMOS, based on the DBE; (2) Theory and demonstration of a novel principle of operation of radiation by spatial power combiners made of arrayed, tightly locked oscillating elements operating at an exceptional point of degeneracy (EPD) present in planar coupled-mode structures. The new principle of operation will be theoretically and experimentally investigated at microwaves and millimeter waves, and compared to existing technology of oscillators and spatial combiners. The proposed research is expected to provide advantages in terms of energy efficiency, more robust oscillation in the presence of load variations, lower phase noise, and improved stability of the frequency of oscillation and radiation. The proposed concepts related to degeneracy conditions have not yet been explored or even proposed in the area of microwave or millimeter-wave circuits. Outcomes of this project may enable future generations of high-efficiency oscillators, distributed amplifiers, as well as novel grid oscillators, which are the backbone of any communication system at microwave and mm-waves.

por.por_cntn:
The knowledge of exceptional points of degeneracy (EPD) in electromagnetic systems has been advanced from the theoretical, practical implementation, and application perspectives. EPD are special degeneracy conditions in systems where two or more eigenstates become fully degenerate, i.e., in their eigenvalues and eigenvectors. For example, in coupled oscillator systems (e.g., two electric resonators or two optical resonators) the natural oscillation frequencies become degenerate as well as the polarization states; in multimode waveguide systems the wavenumbers become degenerate as well as the polarization states of two or more eigenmodes. Several kinds of EPDs have been investigated beyond the standard Parity-Time symmetry condition that has been explored in most of the EPD literature so far. For example, the research widely demonstrated that EPDs occur also in systems without any loss and gain. Various experimental demonstrations have been provided to show that EPDs of order 2, 3, 4, and 6 can be obtained in waveguides and in coupled resonator systems. 

It has been demonstrated theoretically and experimentally that a single resonator with a periodically time modulated component can exhibit EPDs of order 2, hence showing that it is not necessary to couple two resonators to produce an EPD. The linear time varying single resonator operating at the EPD has been shown to be very sensitive to perturbations and at the same time exhibiting low noise. The concept of the "two pole" oscillator has also been demonstrated theoretically and experimentally at radio frequency, relating the ''two-pole'' occurrence to an EPD of order 2 in two coupled electronic resonators with nonlinear gain. This led to a new kind of oscillator with low phase noise that is very sensitive to perturbations of some of its components, a feature that can be used in sensing technology.   

During the duration of the project, two kinds of EPDs in waveguides without loss and gain have been deeply investigated, namely, the degenerate band edge (DBE) and the stationary inflection point (SIP), providing also experimental demonstrations of their occurrence at microwaves. They are EPDs of order 4 and 3, respectively. The new concepts of DBE oscillator and distributed DBE oscillator have been advanced, including the first ever experimental demonstration of the DBE oscillator in a periodic microstrip waveguide with an active element at the center. Unique features of such oscillator have been demonstrated like its independence of load variations, high stability of the oscillation frequency, and low phase noise. Furthermore, the two concepts of energy distribution withing a DBE cavity and the DBE oscillator have been used to demonstrate, theoretically and experimentally, a new way to generate short time-domain pulses. Indeed, a DBE cavity made of a waveguide of finite length has most of its energy concentrated at its center, hence providing the capability of extracting it quickly, i.e., in a short time. 

The above advancements can find applications in a variety of fields, from high power generation at microwave and terahertz frequencies, to sensing technologies. For example, the concept of DBE oscillator provides unique features not shared with other oscillator technologies. When radiating antennas are included in the periodic waveguide, the concept of DBE oscillator seems to provide high power and a collimated beam leading to spatial power combiners from the radiation of arrayed, tightly locked oscillating elements present in a linear coupled-mode structure operating at an EPD. This technique paves the way to conceive planar large apertures of radiators for high power applications for communication, radar, and imaging systems at microwave and mm-waves. High performance electronics is important in a variety of societal applications. The research provided several advancements that may lead to energy-efficient electronics, high power, and high quality of the generated oscillating frequency, which are all key features in modern electronic systems. The research also advanced the new physics-based way of conceiving sensors using EPDs that can be applied to the sensing extremely low concentration of substances or to the sensing of tiny physical changes. The work done involved electromagnetism, mathematics, and electronics, theory and experimentation, hence providing interdisciplinary training to the participating PhD and MS graduate students, and some undergraduate student.
